p: Fish are the most diverse group of freshwater vertebrates and play a central role in the structure and function of freshwater ecosystems [ 13]. They provide food for aquatic and terrestrial consumers (e.g. other fish, reptiles, mammals and birds), can regulate aquatic food webs, cycle nutrients and act as ecosystem engineers [ 14, 15]. In addition, they are providers of valuable goods and services to humans [ 16]. However, the effects of climate change on the functional diversity of freshwater fish remain poorly understood, and the few studies that have used the functional characteristics of species to infer their sensitivity to climate change are mostly restricted to the northern hemisphere (see [ 9, 17]).
